natural problem: A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors?
natural solution: Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.

We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Prod>i::nat\<in>{1..4}. (4-i+1)) / (\<Prod>i::nat\<in>{1..8}. (8-i+1))"
shows  "p = 1 / 35"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Prod>i::nat\<in>{1..4}. (4-i+1)) / (\<Prod>i::nat\<in>{1..8}. (8-i+1))"
shows  "p = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of the fraction $\frac{(4)(3)(2)(1)}{(8)(7)(6)(5)(4)(3)(2)(1)}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda>n. (factorial (4 + n) / (factorial n * factorial (4))) / (factorial (8) / (factorial (4) * factorial (4))))"
shows  "p 4 = 1 / 35"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda>n. (factorial (4 + n) / (factorial n * factorial (4))) / (factorial (8) / (factorial (4) * factorial (4))))"
shows  "p 4 = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of the expression $\frac{\frac{(4+n)!}{n! \cdot 4!}}{\frac{8!}{4! \cdot 4!}}$ when $n = 4$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and prob_alternate_colors :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "prob_alternate_colors = (real (fact (white_balls + black_balls)) / (real (fact white_balls) * real (fact black_balls))) * (1 / 2^(white_balls + black_balls - 1))"
shows  "prob_alternate_colors = 1 / 35"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and prob_alternate_colors :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "prob_alternate_colors = (real (fact (white_balls + black_balls)) / (real (fact white_balls) * real (fact black_balls))) * (1 / 2^(white_balls + black_balls - 1))"
shows  "prob_alternate_colors = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a bag, there are 4 white balls and 4 black balls. If you draw all the balls from the bag one by one, what is the probability that the colors of the balls alternate? The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes W B :: nat and P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "W = 4"
and h1 : "B = 4"
and h2 : "P = (real (fact (W + B)) / (real (fact W) * real (fact B)))"
and h3 : "P = real (binomial (W + B) W)"
shows  "P_alternating = 1 / 35"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes W B :: nat and P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "W = 4"
and h1 : "B = 4"
and h2 : "P = (real (fact (W + B)) / (real (fact W) * real (fact B)))"
and h3 : "P = real (binomial (W + B) W)"
shows  "P_alternating = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a box, there are 4 white balls and 4 black balls. Calculate the probability of choosing a white ball and a black ball alternatively, given that the total number of ways to choose the balls is given by the binomial coefficient. The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and alternating_draws_probability :: rat
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
shows  "alternating_draws_probability = 1 / 35"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and alternating_draws_probability :: rat
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
shows  "alternating_draws_probability = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a bag with 4 white balls and 4 black balls, find the probability of drawing balls from the bag in an alternating sequence (i.e., white-black-white-black or black-white-black-white). The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls total_balls :: real
and alternate_draws_prob :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "total_balls = white_balls + black_balls"
and h3 : "alternate_draws_prob = (white_balls * black_balls * fact (total_balls - 1)) / (fact total_balls)"
shows  "alternate_draws_prob = 1 / 35"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls total_balls :: real
and alternate_draws_prob :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "total_balls = white_balls + black_balls"
and h3 : "alternate_draws_prob = (white_balls * black_balls * fact (total_balls - 1)) / (fact total_balls)"
shows  "alternate_draws_prob = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a box, there are 4 white balls and 4 black balls. If balls are drawn one by one, find the probability that the balls are drawn alternately (starting with either color). The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>n. \<Prod> i::nat \<in> {1..n}. (8 - i) / (9 - i))"
shows  "prob 7 = 1 / 35"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>n. \<Prod> i::nat \<in> {1..n}. (8 - i) / (9 - i))"
shows  "prob 7 = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Suppose we have a probability function, defined as $prob(n) = \prod_{i=1}^n \frac{8-i}{9-i}$. What is the value of $prob(7)$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and total_draws :: nat
and prob_alternate_colors :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "total_draws = white_balls + black_balls"
and h3 : "prob_alternate_colors = 
            (fact (white_balls + black_balls)) / 
            (fact white_balls * fact black_balls * (2 ^ (white_balls + black_balls - 1)))"
shows  "prob_alternate_colors = 1 / 35"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 OR
 We could also compute this based on the probabilities at each step that we draw a ball of the opposite color. If we do that, we get $\frac47 \times \frac36 \times \frac35 \times \frac24 \times \frac23 \times \frac12 = \frac{144}{5040} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls :: nat
and total_draws :: nat
and prob_alternate_colors :: real
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "total_draws = white_balls + black_balls"
and h3 : "prob_alternate_colors = 
            (fact (white_balls + black_balls)) / 
            (fact white_balls * fact black_balls * (2 ^ (white_balls + black_balls - 1)))"
shows  "prob_alternate_colors = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a container, there are 4 white balls and 4 black balls. If all 8 balls are drawn one by one, what is the probability that the colors are drawn alternately, i.e., no two consecutive balls have the same color? The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls alternating_draws :: nat
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "alternating_draws = 1"
shows  "P (alternating_draws) = 1 / 35"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}
 ### Proof
 Let $B$ denote drawing a black ball and $W$ denote drawing a white ball. There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.

 *)

theorem
fixes white_balls black_balls alternating_draws :: nat
assumes h0 : "white_balls = 4"
and h1 : "black_balls = 4"
and h2 : "alternating_draws = 1"
shows  "P (alternating_draws) = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a box, there are 4 white balls and 4 black balls. If you draw balls alternately (white, then black, then white, and so on), what is the probability of drawing 1 white ball and 1 black ball in the first two draws? The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes white black :: nat
assumes h0 : "white = 4"
and h1 : "black = 4"
shows  "probability_alternate_colors white black = 1 / 35"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A box contains 4 white balls and 4 black balls.  I draw them out of the box, one at a time.  What is the probability that all of my draws alternate colors? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{35}

There are two possible successful orders: $BWBWBWBW$ or $WBWBWBWB.$ There are $\binom{8}{4} = 70$ ways to arrange four $B$'s and four $W$'s, so the probability that a random arrangement is successful is $\dfrac{2}{70} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{35}}$.

 *)

theorem
fixes white black :: nat
assumes h0 : "white = 4"
and h1 : "black = 4"
shows  "probability_alternate_colors white black = 1 / 35"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that there are 4 white and 4 black balls, find the probability of picking balls of alternate colors. The final answer is $\frac{1}{35}$.
